access_pathway.primary_pathway_description: Patient downloads a system-wide authorization PDF, checks the 'Myself' box, prints and fills by hand, then faxes or mails to a centralized Release of Information office in Louisville.

red_flags: Sensitive information (mental health, HIV/AIDS, substance use disorder) bundled into single all-or-nothing authorization with no opt-out
Last 4 digits of SSN requested without being marked optional
Outdated form (form-3.pdf) still publicly accessible at a similar URL, risking patient confusion and incorrect mailing address
bright_spots: MyChart is the default delivery method if no preference specified — electronic-first approach
Package-based record selection (Key Documentation vs All Documentation) with detailed descriptions simplifies complex choices
Tips page provides practical guidance on turnaround time (15-day goal), personal representatives, and MyChart support
Toll-free phone number and dedicated MyChart support line (844-764-7820) provided
Multiple delivery options: paper, fax, email, CD, and MyChart

findability.rationale: Level 4: Forms easily found via basic web search and medical records page; directly downloadable without obstacles. Not a 5 because no Lexington-specific form exists — patient must recognize the system-wide form applies.

technical_accessibility.rationale: Level 3: Form has a text layer (not a scan) and could be annotated with PDF editor workarounds, and fax submission is available. However, zero fillable fields means the workflow is fundamentally print-and-handwrite before faxing.

content_design.rationale: Level 4: Well-organized with clear section headers, logical flow, helpful package descriptions, and a practical tips page. Minor issues with dense legal text on page 2 and bundled sensitive information consent prevent a 5.

patient_centeredness.rationale: Level 4: Patient access is clearly accommodated via a prominent 'Myself' checkbox, purpose field waived for patient self-requests, MyChart default delivery, and a dedicated (if outdated) patient access form exists. Not a 5 because the primary form is still a generic authorization, not purpose-built for patient self-access.

compliance.rationale: Level 4: No notarization required, voluntary authorization statement present, revocation rights clearly explained, 15-day turnaround goal stated. Minor ambiguities: SSN collection not marked optional, sensitive info bundled without granular opt-out, no fee disclosure.

overall.summary: Baptist Health Lexington provides a competent, well-organized records request process through its parent system with clear patient self-access accommodation, but the non-fillable PDF and paper-based workflow prevent it from reaching the highest tiers.
